operation.descriptionCdata:
a35b9064-e6d4-4598-b74f-d7cad742bea8.206c4568-a677-476b-8dcf-7efeea7fdbc6.prompt=Password\: a35b9064-e6d4-4598-b74f-d7cad742bea8.2229233c-b53d-4d12-aae4-205e77a03c42.prompt=Host Name\: a35b9064-e6d4-4598-b74f-d7cad742bea8.3acf1d16-338c-4603-8eef-7df9fa191928.prompt=Username\: a35b9064-e6d4-4598-b74f-d7cad742bea8.45df132c-d5d8-4b2c-b0ad-f8a20ebf7f83.prompt=Use SSL? a35b9064-e6d4-4598-b74f-d7cad742bea8.6beabcff-cef8-4416-a233-a32765d9de01.prompt=Execution Policy Scope\: a35b9064-e6d4-4598-b74f-d7cad742bea8.description=
Changes the user preference for the Windows PowerShell execution policy. It determines whether configuration files (including Windows PowerShell profile) can be loaded and scripts can be executed. It also determines which scripts, if any, must be digitally signed before they will execute.

When Set Execution Policy is used in any scope other than Process, the new user preference is saved in the registry and remains unchanged until the next change. When the value of the Scope parameter is Process, the user preference is stored in the PSExecutionPolicyPreference environment variable ($env\:PSExecutionPolicyPreference), instead of the registry, and it is deleted when the session in which it is effective is closed.

If the "Turn on Script Execution" Group Policy is enabled for the computer or user, the user preference is saved, but it is not effective, and Windows PowerShell displays a message explaining the conflict. Set Execution Policy cannot be used to override a Group Policy, even if the user preference is more restrictive than the policy.

Remoting must be enabled on the target computer to run this operation remotely. Go to http\://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/ff700227.aspx for instructions on how to enable remoting on a Windows computer.

For more on execution policies, go to http\://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd347641.aspx

Inputs\: 
host	- The host name or the IP address of the target Windows computer.
username	- Username to use for thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation (can be left blank). The user to execute the PowerShell script as.
password	- Password of the user.
policy	- The execution policy that should be set. Valid values are-
		Restricted	\: Does not load configuration files or run scripts. This is the default value.
		AllSigned	\: Requires that all scripts and configuration files be signed by a trusted publisher, including scripts created on the local computer.
		RemoteSigned\: Requires that all scripts and configuration files downloaded from the Internet be signed by a trusted publisher.
		Unrestricted	\: Loads all configuration files and runs all scripts. Unsigned script downloaded from the Internet will be prompted for permission before it runs.
		Bypass	\: Nothing is blocked and there are no warnings or prompts.
		Undefined	\: Removes the currently assigned execution policy from the current scope. This parameter will not remove an execution policy that is set in a Group Policy scope.
scope	- The scope of the execution policy that should be set. It defaults to "LocalMachine". When executed in a PowerShell v1.0 context, the user input for this parameter is ignored. Valid values are- 
		Process	\: Affects only the current Windows PowerShell process.
		CurrentUser	\: Affects only the current user.
		LocalMachine	\: Affects all users of the computer. This is the default value.
		MachinePolicy\: Execution policy set by a Group Policy for all users of the computer.
		UserPolicy	\: Execution policy set by a Group Policy for the current user of the computer
ssl         	- Whether SSL should be used while invoking the script remotely. This input defaults to false, and is ignored for local script execution. If SSL is not available on the port used for the operation, the operation will fail.

Responses\:
success	- The command ran successfully.
failure	- The command failed to run.

Result\:
The return code of the operation.

Extra Results\:
returnResult	- The result of the script execution.

Note\: 
1. This operation does not support Remoting on PowerShell 1.0.

2. When the execution policy is set for the Process scope using this operation, it is valid only for the PowerShell context in which it is invoked and will not be available in subsequent PowerShell contexts.

3. If the target computer is not present in the list of Trusted Hosts in WS-Management of the RAS host, the operation may fail when using the target computer's system account as user credentials.

4. In Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, and later versions of Windows, Operations Orchestration must be started with the "Run as administrator" option to change the execution policy for the default (LocalMachine) scope.
a35b9064-e6d4-4598-b74f-d7cad742bea8.e9f4ccbd-aa12-43a6-92d4-cd94cd50a64a.prompt=Execution Policy\:
operation.name: Set Execution Policy
